sec.title: Texts
sec.p: 1. This princely estate, so well known to our elderly citizens [was] situated on a commanding eminence, surrounded by groves of ancient trees [and] extended, through intervening vales to the shores washed by the waters of the Hudson. The hand of art and the guidance of taste had adorned its broad expanse of cultivated grounds with the luxuriance of gardens, arbors and shrubberies; while Nature lent to the perfection of the landscape … the ripening influences of her beneficence…

… [Mortier] erected on [this] conspicuous eminence, a spatious and imposing edifice to which he gave the designation ‘Richmond Hill’. He speedily commenced … on a scale of generous expenditure [using ‘no small part of his fortune’] to improve and ornament its grounds. (Prosper Wetmore 1872 Appendix II: 8–9 in Stone 1872).

2[2a] I write you, my dear sister … from the peaceful borders of the Hudson … where the hand of nature has so lavishly displayed her beauties, that she has left scarcely any thing for her handmaiden, art, to perform.

[2b] The house in which we reside is situated upon a hill, the avenue to which is inter-spersed with forest trees, under which a shrubbery rather too luxurious and wild, has taken shelter, owing to its having been deprived, by death, some years since of its original proprietor, who kept it in perfect order.

[2c] In front of the house the noble Hudson rolls its majestic waves, bearing upon his bosom … innumerable small vessels, which are constantly forwarding the rich products of the neighboring soil to the busy hand of a more extensive commerce. Beyond the Hudson rises to our view the fertile country of the Jerseys, covered with a golden harvest. … On the right hand [northward], an extensive plain presents us with a view of fields, covered with verdure, and pastures full of cattle. On the left [southward], the city [New York] opens upon us, intercepted only by clumps of trees, and some rising ground, which serves to heighten the beauty of the scene, by appearing to conceal a part. In the background [at the back of the house] is a large flower garden, enclosed with a hedge, and some very handsome trees. On one side of it a grove of pines and oaks … (Abigail Adams, 27 September 1789. In: A. Adams (1848: 343–4). [The garden is described in an earlier letter (12 July 1789) as having ‘a Hawthorne hedge and Rows of Trees with a Broad Gravel Walk’ (Adams 1947: 18)].

3. Yesterday dined with me, the King of the Mohawks, Colonel Brandt [sic] – he has left town [for New York] this morning with a letter of introduction to Theodosia. … Colonel Brandt has an elegant house in the English style in the midst of his nation … and lives with great taste and hospitality.’ [Burr also notes Brant’s association during his visit in England with ‘nobility and gentry’] … you may ask him to breakfast with you, if he accepts, let Theodosia ask … [Burr names two respectable New York residents] to be of the party. … They will be pleased to meet so well informed…an indian’ (Burr to [John Vanderlyn?], 2/26/1797, Burr Family Collection, Ms.Grp.#303, Yale University Library; in Burr Papers, reel 4).

4. The ‘premises followed the fortunes of other localities; the street commissioner made his influence felt; streets and avenues were opened; … hills disappeared … until at length the old Richmond Hill mansion found itself shorn of all its grandeur, stripped of its verdant groves, despoiled of its gardens and lawns, sitting sadly far beneath its former altitude, at the noisey and somewhat unsavoury corner of Charleton and Varick Streets. Its stately portals no longer opened wide to welcome the entrance of distinguished guests from foreign lands. (Prosper Wetmore 1872: 9–10, appendix)

5. [5a] [We] took a walk … over what I recollected as the [boyhood] playground of myself and my companions … and what Mr. De Viellecour remembered as the spot where his contemporaries at an early period used to shoot quails and wood-cocks. We passed over a part of the city which in my time had been hills, hollows, marshes and rivulets without having observed anything to awaken … a recollection of what the place was before the surface had been levelled and the houses erected, until, arriving at the corner of Charlton and Varick streets, we came to an edifice utterly dissimilar to anything around it. [It was] a wooden building … with a [lofty] portico supported by ionic columns … [and] its [whole] appearance distinguished by that Palladian character of … ornament, which indicated … it had been built about the middle of the last century. [We both stopped involuntarily before it.]

[5b] ‘If I did not see that house on a flat plain,’ said Mr. De Viellecour, ‘penned in by this little gravelly courtyard, and surrounded by these starveling catalpas and horse-chestnuts, I should say at once that it was a mansion which I [very] well remember, where in my youth I passed many pleasant hours in the society of its hospitable owner. … That house resembled this exactly, but then it was upon a noble hill, several hundred feet* in height, commanding a view of the river and the Jersey shore. There was a … fine rich lawn around it, shaded by … venerable oaks … and skirted on every side by a … natural wood of … [many] acres.

[5c] … Perceiving it to be a house of public entertainment, [we entered it] [and] … went into a spacious hall opening up to a more spacious room, with a small room on each side, opening to more spacious apartments beyond. ‘Yes,’ said Mr. Viellecour, ‘this is certainly the house I spoke of.’ … With the air of a man accustomed to the building, [he] opened a side door … and began to ascend a wide stair-case with a heavy mahogany railing. … [Going into a large second-storey room:] ‘Yes’, said my friend, here was the dining room. There, in the center of the table sat Vice President Adams, in full dress … his hair frizzed out each side of his face, as you see in Stuart’s older pictures of him. [There follow details of the eminent guests, their elaborate clothing and their seating position at the table, including Viellecour’s own seating. A central figure in this tale is the French ambassador ‘in his red-heeled shoes and ear-rings’ who, declining ‘all the luxuries of the table … from the roast beef down to the lobsters’ distributed to the guests instead his own specially prepared ‘warm pie of truffles and game.’] … I can attest to the truth of the story, and the excellence of the pate [said Mr Viellecour].

[5d] [After suggesting that they] go, and look at the fine view from the balcony, [Mr Viellecour] seemed disappointed at finding the view he spoke of confined to the opposite side of Varick street, built up with two story brick houses, while … ragged boys were playing marbles on the side walks. ‘Well,’ said he, ‘the view is gone, that is clear enough; but I cannot … understand how the house has got so much lower than formerly.’

I [Mr Herbert] explained to my friend the omnipotence of the [City] Corporation, by which every high hill has been brought low … and by which … this house had been abased to a level with its humbler neighbors. …

[5e] ‘This is wrong,’ said the old gentleman, ‘These New-Yorkers seem to take a pleasure in defacing the monuments of the good old times … depriving themselves of all venerable and patriotic associations. This house should have been continued in its old situation, on its own original … eminence, where its very aspect would have suggested its history (Bryant et al. 1830: 338–342).

bio.p: Nancy D Munn is Professor Emerita in the Department of Anthropology, University of Chicago. She has done field research in central Australia and on Gawa Island, PNG. She is currently writing a book on place-change in early 19th century New York. Previous papers include: ‘The Becoming Past of Places: Space, time and Memory in … pre-civil war New York.’ Suomen Antropologi v.29(1),1995; and ‘The Symbolic Construction of Memory in the Kaluli Gisalo' in Cosmos and Society in Oceania., ed. by D.de Coppet and A. Iteanu. Berg.
